title: Rrythm Music Bot
header: A modernized Rythm Bot clone created with my interpretation
story: Ever since Rythm got shut down in 2021 by YouTube, I noticed that my friends were spending less time hanging around on Discord voice calls during the pandemic isolation. Firstly, what the heck, YouTube. Not cool. Secondly, I pondered if I could remake the bot myself. An innocent Google search and a few YouTube videos eventually led me to develop a fully functional backend bot that I now locally host on my Raspberry Pi using a Python script. This is one of my first major successes with programming and remains to be my proudest achievement.
desc: Backend Discord bot that takes user input and streams audio from a YouTube source
Utilized object-oriented programming to organize functions and data from API requests
Learned how to read API documentation, use version control (git), organize code in File Explorer, and structure code neatly with adaquate documentation to enable maintainability
Implemented a customized queue data structure
Painfully understood the concept of Promises, async, await through raw trial and error
Coded without ChatGPT or AI tomfoolery

title: HealthChain
header: DeltaHacks IX winner for "Most Innovative Use of Verbwire API"
story: It was all one day when a friend of mine asked me to sign up with him for a hackathon hosted at his university. I was like 'why the heck not'! After all, this seems like it'd be a good opportunity to see how good my coding skills are (spoiler alert: I was humbled much). We created a IPFS uploader for medical practioners to upload data-sensitive documents on to the Ethereum blockchain. As the one in charge of the backend, I initially intended to use Verbwire to do the uploading, but the documentation example doesn't work, and so I switched to use Moralis instead. Funnily enough, this still won 'Most Innovative Use of Verbwire API' thanks to our ingenious idea. That, or a challenge with awards for 10 groups, got only 10 groups signing up.
desc: Used "Verbwire" API to upload PDF files onto the Ethereum blockchain
Developed failsafe system where if uploading via Verbwire failed, Moralis will be used instead (on early implementations)
Programmatically connected friend's frontend with my backend
Victorious in the "I-had-no-idea-what-I-was-doing-mindset-but-it-still-worked" mindset

title: Tip Tap Type
story: This was a Greenfoot project that I worked on with a few of my high school friends. The primarily objective of this project was to practically use data structures, with the theme of creating a word-related game. This was a daunting project, but we managed to give it everything it needs to be called a game ranging from music, sound effects, animations, and UI.
desc: Coded in the worst IDE ever known to humanity
Developed the core typing algorithm using an implemented Stack data structure
Enhanced typing endurance because it's Java

title: Personal Website
header: A virtual presentation of myself; what you're seeing right now!
story: Yeah, I'm pretty sure I know how to use semicolons. This was a very fun project for me. Don't need any wix or weebly here >:). It took me about 3 days to get through TheNetNinja's ReactJS tutorials and then essentially forever to get this website up and going. If I had any regrets in life, that would be having a preference in improvising over planning. Oh my god I am 100% going to recode this from ground-up when I have the time to do so. With that being said, my suggestion to you, dear reader (of course I have to assume someone is reading my website), is to NOT checkout the CSS in the GitHub and intentinally resize this window :)
desc: Learned ReactJS and CSS in a short time frame (1 week) to develop a personal website
Experimented with Figma and learned how to mockup websites
Learned how to set and achieve goals to ensure this personal project is on track to completion
Attempted to study modern website design to implement on website
Perfected the art of Ctrl+C and Ctrl+V
